elements.content: A porous metal–organic framework (MOF), Fe4(μ3-O)2(BTB)8/3(DMF)2(H2O)2·(DMF)10(H2O)2 (1) (BTB = benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoate, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) has two interpenetrating 3D frameworks composed of fused cages and shows a stronger affinity for CO2 than most other known highly porous MOFs. The unique tetranuclear iron–oxo clusters act as 8-connectors, which are linked by 3-connecting BTBs, to give a partially augmented the net (using the symbolism of O’Keeffe and co-workers). The underlying implications for (3,8)-coordinated networks are also discussed in relation to the framework structure of 1.
elements.clean_text: A porous metal-organic framework (MOF), Fe4(μ3-O)2(BTB)8/3(DMF)2(H2O)2⋅(DMF)10(H2O)2 (1) (BTB = benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoate, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) has two interpenetrating 3D frameworks composed of fused cages and shows a stronger affinity for CO2 than most other known highly porous MOFs. The unique tetranuclear iron-oxo clusters act as 8-connectors, which are linked by 3-connecting BTBs, to give a partially augmented the net (using the symbolism of O'Keeffe and co-workers). The underlying implications for (3,8)-coordinated networks are also discussed in relation to the framework structure of 1.

elements.content:
A (3,8)-coordinated and interpenetrated metal–organic framework (MOF) containing [Fe4(μ3-O)2]8+ clusters shows a stronger affinity for CO2 than most other known highly porous MOFs.

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline, extended structures composed of inorganic and organic secondary building units (SBUs), such as metal oxide clusters and aromatic polycarboxylates. They have potential applicability in such fields as magnetism, molecular separation, chiral catalysis, and fuel gas or CO2 storage. This versatility stems from their unique structures, which have sufficient rigidity to maintain nanosized pores and, in some cases, dynamic responses to guest species. It is expected that additional novel properties or niche applications will be discovered as our knowledge of the available MOF structure types is expanded; however, the common topologies (i.e., the nets describing the geometric connectivity of the SBUs) that MOFs adopt is small in number. To discover MOFs with greater structural diversity, it is a prerequisite to synthesize new types of SBUs. Already, square M2(O2C–)4, octahedral Zn4O(O2C–)6, and trigonal prismatic M3O(O2C–)6 clusters have been widely used to assemble highly porous materials. Here, we report the synthesis, structure, and properties of an interpenetrated, porous material assembled from 8-coordinated prismatoid iron–oxo clusters.
elements.clean_text:
A (3,8)-coordinated and interpenetrated metal-organic framework (MOF) containing [Fe4(μ3-O)2]8+ clusters shows a stronger affinity for CO2 than most other known highly porous MOFs.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline, extended structures composed of inorganic and organic secondary building units (SBUs), such as metal oxide clusters and aromatic polycarboxylates. They have potential applicability in such fields as magnetism, molecular separation, chiral catalysis, and fuel gas or CO2 storage. This versatility stems from their unique structures, which have sufficient rigidity to maintain nanosized pores and, in some cases, dynamic responses to guest species. It is expected that additional novel properties or niche applications will be discovered as our knowledge of the available MOF structure types is expanded; however, the common topologies (i.e., the nets describing the geometric connectivity of the SBUs) that MOFs adopt is small in number. To discover MOFs with greater structural diversity, it is a prerequisite to synthesize new types of SBUs. Already, square M2(O2C-)4, octahedral Zn4O(O2C-)6, and trigonal prismatic M3O(O2C-)6 clusters have been widely used to assemble highly porous materials. Here, we report the synthesis, structure, and properties of an interpenetrated, porous material assembled from 8-coordinated prismatoid iron-oxo clusters.

elements.content: When benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoic acid (H3BTB) (0.12 g, 0.27 mmol) and FeCl2·4H2O (0.22 g, 1.1 mmol) in 10.0 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were heated in a sealed tube at 130 °C for 1 day, dark brown cubic crystals were formed, of which bulk-phase purity was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). Using a combination of elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) measurement, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, the material was formulated as Fe4O2(BTB)8/3(DMF)2(H2O)2·(DMF)10(H2O)2 (1), with the structure illustrated in Figure .
elements.clean_text: When benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoic acid (H3BTB) (0.12 g, 0.27 mmol) and FeCl2⋅4H2O (0.22 g, 1.1 mmol) in 10.0 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were heated in a sealed tube at 130 °C for 1 day, dark brown cubic crystals were formed, of which bulk-phase purity was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). Using a combination of elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) measurement, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, the material was formulated as Fe4O2(BTB)8/3(DMF)2(H2O)2⋅(DMF)10(H2O)2 (1), with the structure illustrated in Figure .

elements.content: Description of the crystal structure of 1. (a) Thermal ellipsoid plot of a structural fragment highlighting the organic and inorganic SBUs, drawn with 50% probabilities. An inversion center is located in the middle of the Fe4(μ3-O)2 cluster. O(1S) is a DMF oxygen atom, and O(10) is a coordinated water oxygen atom. Hydrogen bonds are drawn as dashed lines. (b) A BTB link can be schematized as a 3-connector; similarly, the Fe4(μ3-O)2(O2C–)8 inorganic SBU is drawn as a prism of vertices. (c) The material is composed of two interpenetrated frameworks, each constructed by linking the SBUs described in (b).
elements.clean_text: 1  Description of the crystal structure of 1. (a) Thermal ellipsoid plot of a structural fragment highlighting the organic and inorganic SBUs, drawn with 50% probabilities. An inversion center is located in the middle of the Fe4(μ3-O)2 cluster. O(1S) is a DMF oxygen atom, and O(10) is a coordinated water oxygen atom. Hydrogen bonds are drawn as dashed lines. (b) A BTB link can be schematized as a 3-connector; similarly, the Fe4(μ3-O)2(O2C-)8 inorganic SBU is drawn as a prism of vertices. (c) The material is composed of two interpenetrated frameworks, each constructed by linking the SBUs described in (b).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 1 contains an iron–oxo cluster, wherein four octahedrally coordinated cations are bridged by two pyramidalized μ3-O (Figure a). The four Fe atoms are coplanar; Fe(1) and its symmetry equivalent, Fe(1a), are ligated by four carboxylate oxygens, a DMF oxygen atom, and a μ3-O, while Fe(2) and Fe(2a) are ligated by three carboxylate oxygens, a water molecule, and two μ3-O. The bonds between Fe and μ3-O are 1.837(3) and 1.927(3) Å for Fe(1) and Fe(2), respectively, and the Fe–O(carboxylate) bonds range in length from 1.958(3) to 2.054(3) Å, which are typical of FeIII–O bonds. Bond valence sum analysis and SQUID magnetic data support the assignment of oxidation state +3 to all Fe atoms, with high spin d 5 configurations (see the ). The two μ3-O atoms are located on opposite sides of the mean plane defined by the four Fe atoms, with a deviation of 0.274(2) Å. The structural features are similar to those in the molecular [Fe4(μ3-O)2(O2CCMe3)8(2-pic)2] complex, where eight carboxylate groups ligate four Fe atoms in a bridging-monodentate fashion. c In comparison to this molecular counterpart, 1 contains six bridging dimonodentate carboxylates and two monodentate ones, in which noncoordinated oxygen atoms form hydrogen bonds with the coordinated water molecules [O(10)···O(4) = 2.816(5) Å]. This bonding arrangement is probably related to the geometric requirements for the underlying topology of the material, which is discussed in greater detail below.
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of 1 contains an iron-oxo cluster, wherein four octahedrally coordinated cations are bridged by two pyramidalized μ3-O (Figure a). The four Fe atoms are coplanar; Fe(1) and its symmetry equivalent, Fe(1a), are ligated by four carboxylate oxygens, a DMF oxygen atom, and a μ3-O, while Fe(2) and Fe(2a) are ligated by three carboxylate oxygens, a water molecule, and two μ3-O. The bonds between Fe and μ3-O are 1.837(3) and 1.927(3) Å for Fe(1) and Fe(2), respectively, and the Fe-O(carboxylate) bonds range in length from 1.958(3) to 2.054(3) Å, which are typical of FeIII-O bonds. Bond valence sum analysis and SQUID magnetic data support the assignment of oxidation state +3 to all Fe atoms, with high spin d 5 configurations (see the ). The two μ3-O atoms are located on opposite sides of the mean plane defined by the four Fe atoms, with a deviation of 0.274(2) Å. The structural features are similar to those in the molecular [Fe4(μ3-O)2(O2CCMe3)8(2-pic)2] complex, where eight carboxylate groups ligate four Fe atoms in a bridging-monodentate fashion. c In comparison to this molecular counterpart, 1 contains six bridging dimonodentate carboxylates and two monodentate ones, in which noncoordinated oxygen atoms form hydrogen bonds with the coordinated water molecules [O(10)⋅⋅⋅O(4) = 2.816(5) Å]. This bonding arrangement is probably related to the geometric requirements for the underlying topology of the material, which is discussed in greater detail below.

elements.content: As in other MOFs, the connectivity of the inorganic clusters has important consequences for the porosity of the material. The organic link used to assemble 1 is a trigonal tricarboxylate, and eight of these are bound to each inorganic cluster. Following the conventional SBU analysis scheme, the eight carboxylate C atoms of the inorganic cluster are designated the points of extension. These define a distorted prismatoid or more precisely a solid facetted by six convex, skew quadrilaterals. A net that describes the topology of 1 can be constructed by connecting these vertices to each other and to the 3-coordinated vertices, which describe the organic links (Figure b). The resulting net is ideally cubic but rhombohedrally distorted in this material, defining two types of cages. Due to the relative size of the larger of these cages, its apertures, and the high symmetry of the topology, material 1 forms as two independent frameworks that are interpenetrated (Figure c).
elements.clean_text: As in other MOFs, the connectivity of the inorganic clusters has important consequences for the porosity of the material. The organic link used to assemble 1 is a trigonal tricarboxylate, and eight of these are bound to each inorganic cluster. Following the conventional SBU analysis scheme, the eight carboxylate C atoms of the inorganic cluster are designated the points of extension. These define a distorted prismatoid or more precisely a solid facetted by six convex, skew quadrilaterals. A net that describes the topology of 1 can be constructed by connecting these vertices to each other and to the 3-coordinated vertices, which describe the organic links (Figure b). The resulting net is ideally cubic but rhombohedrally distorted in this material, defining two types of cages. Due to the relative size of the larger of these cages, its apertures, and the high symmetry of the topology, material 1 forms as two independent frameworks that are interpenetrated (Figure c).

elements.content: While interpenetration diminishes the total pore volume available in the material, the calculated solvent-accessible volume (using the calc solv routine in PLATON) is 50.1% of the crystal structure, including the coordinated water and DMF molecules. Pores 10 Å in diameter reside within the second type of cage, defined by an approximate octahedron of Fe4(μ3-O)2(O2C–)8 clusters connected through eight BTB links. These pores are accessible through elliptical apertures measuring 4.0 × 8.0 Å. TGAs indicated that the solvent molecules residing in the pores of 1 could be removed by heating to 150 °C (see the ). Measured adsorption of N2 by 1 at 77 K yielded a reversible, nonhysteretic type-I isotherm. From these data, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir apparent surface areas were calculated as 1121 and 1835 m2 g−1, respectively, and the pore volume was calculated as 0.69 cm3 g−1. The material also reversibly adsorbs up to 2.1 wt % of hydrogen gas at 77 K and 1 bar (see the ).
elements.clean_text: While interpenetration diminishes the total pore volume available in the material, the calculated solvent-accessible volume (using the calc solv routine in PLATON) is 50.1% of the crystal structure, including the coordinated water and DMF molecules. Pores 10 Å in diameter reside within the second type of cage, defined by an approximate octahedron of Fe4(μ3-O)2(O2C-)8 clusters connected through eight BTB links. These pores are accessible through elliptical apertures measuring 4.0 × 8.0 Å. TGAs indicated that the solvent molecules residing in the pores of 1 could be removed by heating to 150 °C (see the ). Measured adsorption of N2 by 1 at 77 K yielded a reversible, nonhysteretic type-I isotherm. From these data, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir apparent surface areas were calculated as 1121 and 1835 m2 g-1, respectively, and the pore volume was calculated as 0.69 cm3 g-1. The material also reversibly adsorbs up to 2.1 wt % of hydrogen gas at 77 K and 1 bar (see the ).

elements.content: Material 1 also shows an enhanced affinity for CO2 compared to many other porous MOFs. Adsorption isotherm data measured over a range of temperature (see Figure a) were used to calculate the isosteric adsorption enthalpy, giving values of 28.3 kJ mol−1 by the Toth method and 26.4 kJ mol−1 using a variant of the Clausius–Clapeyron equation. At 273 K, under low-pressure (<1 bar) conditions, material 1 demonstrated a greater uptake of CO2 than several other well-known, highly porous MOFs (Figure b). Our independent syntheses and N2 adsorption analyses confirmed that each of these materials (MOF-5, MOF-14, MOF-177, MIL-100, and MIL-101) has a larger apparent surface area and pore volume than 1 (see the ). These results suggest stronger interactions between CO2 and the surface of 1 at low loadings, perhaps achieved by sharper surface-charge gradients on the Fe4(μ3-O)2(O2C–)8 clusters, the constriction of the pores by interpenetration, or a synergy of these effects. Wang et al. measured larger isosteric adsorption enthalpies for CO2 in zeolite NaX and HKUST-1, a MOF containing coordinatively unsaturated CuII. The latter material adsorbed more than twice the CO2 of 1 at 1 bar and room temperature, consistent with larger surface adsorption potentials associated with its inorganic SBUs.

At 273 K, under low-pressure (<1 bar) conditions, material 1 demonstrated a greater uptake of CO2 than several other well-known, highly porous MOFs (Figure b). Our independent syntheses and N2 adsorption analyses confirmed that each of these materials (MOF-5, MOF-14, MOF-177, MIL-100, and MIL-101) has a larger apparent surface area and pore volume than 1 (see the ). These results suggest stronger interactions between CO2 and the surface of 1 at low loadings, perhaps achieved by sharper surface-charge gradients on the Fe4(μ3-O)2(O2C-)8 clusters, the constriction of the pores by interpenetration, or a synergy of these effects. Wang et al. measured larger isosteric adsorption enthalpies for CO2 in zeolite NaX and HKUST-1, a MOF containing coordinatively unsaturated CuII. The latter material adsorbed more than twice the CO2 of 1 at 1 bar and room temperature, consistent with larger surface adsorption potentials associated with its inorganic SBUs.

elements.content: (a) CO2 adsorption isotherms of 1 collected at various temperatures. CO2 was reversibly desorbed at each temperature. (b) CO2 adsorption isotherms measured at 273 K for several known MOFs are shown for a comparison. Literature references for each material are listed in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) CO2 adsorption isotherms of 1 collected at various temperatures. CO2 was reversibly desorbed at each temperature. (b) CO2 adsorption isotherms measured at 273 K for several known MOFs are shown for a comparison. Literature references for each material are listed in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Further discussion of the mixed-coordination net underlying 1 is pertinent, because using larger coordination SBUs is an important route to new structures, and it is informative to identify their commonly occurring nets. In the simplest sense, an Fe4(μ3-O)2(O2C–)8 cluster can be considered a single vertex, 8-coordinated by BTB centroids, with the framework connectivity thereafter being described by a net composed of alternating 3- and 8-coordinated vertices. A cubic net with these properties has been described previously as the the or Moravia net, and the net illustrated in Figure c is an augmented version of this, with eight 4-vertices replacing the 8-vertices. The scheme in Figure illustrates how several chemically relevant cubic nets can be related by the addition, deletion, or replacement of vertices, such as through decoration or augmentation. Starting with the primitive cubic net (pcu), the reo net (exemplified by the O atoms in ReO3) is generated by decorating each 6-vertex by three 8-vertices to form an array of vertex-shared octahedra. Decoration of the reo net with squares of 4-vertices gives the sodalite net (sod), while augmentation yields the net of zeolite A (lta). On the other hand, the addition of 3-vertices at the centroids of all 3-rings in the reo net yields the the net after removing the links between 8-vertices. As discussed above, augmentation of the 8-vertices in the gives the net shown in Figure c, which can be used to describe material 1. It is also interesting to note that appropriate removal of half of the 3-vertices in the or appropriate addition of 3-vertices to reo can yield bor (net of the B atoms in boracite) or tbo (“twisted” boracite). The increased usage of trigonal links has borne several MOFs describable by bor, tbo, or their augmented forms.

A cubic net with these properties has been described previously as the the  or Moravia net, and the net illustrated in Figure c is an augmented version of this, with eight 4-vertices replacing the 8-vertices. The scheme in Figure  illustrates how several chemically relevant cubic nets can be related by the addition, deletion, or replacement of vertices, such as through decoration or augmentation. Starting with the primitive cubic net (pcu), the reo net (exemplified by the O atoms in ReO3) is generated by decorating each 6-vertex by three 8-vertices to form an array of vertex-shared octahedra. Decoration of the reo net with squares of 4-vertices gives the sodalite net (sod), while augmentation yields the net of zeolite A (lta). On the other hand, the addition of 3-vertices at the centroids of all 3-rings in the reo net yields the the net after removing the links between 8-vertices. It is also interesting to note that appropriate removal of half of the 3-vertices in the or appropriate addition of 3-vertices to reo can yield bor (net of the B atoms in boracite) or tbo ("twisted" boracite). The increased usage of trigonal links has borne several MOFs describable by bor, tbo, or their augmented forms.

elements.content: Relationships between some decorated forms of the primitive cubic net (pcu) with chemical relevance. Nets are defined by arrays of linked vertices (balls and sticks); polyhedral shading has been added to aid visualization. The net pcu is 6-coordinated; reo is 8-coordinated; sod and lta are 4-coordinated; bor, tbo, and partially augmented the are (3,4)-coordinated; and the is (3,8)-coordinated.
elements.clean_text: 3  Relationships between some decorated forms of the primitive cubic net (pcu) with chemical relevance. Nets are defined by arrays of linked vertices (balls and sticks); polyhedral shading has been added to aid visualization. The net pcu is 6-coordinated; reo is 8-coordinated; sod and lta are 4-coordinated; bor, tbo, and partially augmented the are (3,4)-coordinated; and the is (3,8)-coordinated.

elements.content: Since 8-coordinated SBUs are rare and the use of trigonal SBUs, such as BTB, is still gaining momentum, there are very few examples of MOFs with (3,8)-coordinated nets or their augmented forms. Of the three literature examples that we have identified, however, all adopt the simple or augmented the net. This suggests that the is the default (3,8)-coordinated net, which is not surprising given its high symmetry. This identification of the default net brings with it the logical prediction of widespread interpenetration in materials that assemble according to its topology. Just as materials with the pcu topology are prone to interpenetration because of self-dualism, materials with decorated pcu topologies are commonly observed in interpenetrated arrangements if their metrics allow it. The consequent diminution of the pore volume in such materials is mollified in those with cubic nets that have large secondary cages, as has been demonstrated in 1.
elements.clean_text: Since 8-coordinated SBUs are rare and the use of trigonal SBUs, such as BTB, is still gaining momentum, there are very few examples of MOFs with (3,8)-coordinated nets or their augmented forms. Of the three literature examples that we have identified, however, all adopt the simple or augmented the net. This suggests that the is the default (3,8)-coordinated net, which is not surprising given its high symmetry. This identification of the default net brings with it the logical prediction of widespread interpenetration in materials that assemble according to its topology. Just as materials with the pcu topology are prone to interpenetration because of self-dualism, materials with decorated pcu topologies are commonly observed in interpenetrated arrangements if their metrics allow it. The consequent diminution of the pore volume in such materials is mollified in those with cubic nets that have large secondary cages, as has been demonstrated in 1.

elements.content: A final note to be made regarding the employment of 8-coordinated SBUs concerns their use in assembling materials with zeolite framework topologies. Due to the large diversity of nets that zeolites exemplify, attention has been paid to 4-coordinated MOFs assembled with similar connectivities. Obtaining materials with zeolite-like topologies is challenging because of the proclivity of tetrahedral SBUs to assemble with the diamond (dia) topology. Following from the discussion above, a zeolite net containing double 4-rings (D4R), such as lta, can be emulated by using 8-coordinated SBUs if these are interpreted as augmentations by eight 4-vertices (see Figure ). In fact, the augmented form of the shown in Figures c and is very similar to the topology of zeolite ITQ-21, with the 4-coordination of that net being completed by additional 4-rings within the octahedral cages.

Due to the large diversity of nets that zeolites exemplify, attention has been paid to 4-coordinated MOFs assembled with similar connectivities. Obtaining materials with zeolite-like topologies is challenging because of the proclivity of tetrahedral SBUs to assemble with the diamond (dia) topology. Following from the discussion above, a zeolite net containing double 4-rings (D4R), such as lta, can be emulated by using 8-coordinated SBUs if these are interpreted as augmentations by eight 4-vertices (see Figure ). In fact, the augmented form of the shown in Figures c and  is very similar to the topology of zeolite ITQ-21, with the 4-coordination of that net being completed by additional 4-rings within the octahedral cages.

elements.content: Experimental data and procedures for the syntheses and characterization of 1 (NMR, IR, EA, TGA, and XRD data), additional figures describing the structure of 1, X-ray crystallographic information file (CIF), and gas (N2, H2, and CO2) sorption measurements of 1 and other porous MOFs. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: Crystal data of 1: C108H132N12O34Fe4, M r = 2365.66, rhombohedral, space group R(−3), a = b = 38.2457(15) Å, c = 20.8226(15) Å, V = 26 377(2) Å3, Z = 9, d calcd = 1.340 g cm–3, T = 258(2) K, λ = 0.710 73 Å, 2θ = 56.66°, 57 309 collected, 14 112 independent reflections, R 1 = 0.0648 [I > 2σ(I), 4889 reflections], wR 2 = 0.1677 (all data). Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) 632182 contains the crystallographic data in CIF files.

cln_elements.content:
While interpenetration diminishes the total pore volume available in the material, the calculated solvent-accessible volume (using the calc solv routine in PLATON) is 50.1% of the crystal structure, including the coordinated water and DMF molecules. Pores 10 Å in diameter reside within the second type of cage, defined by an approximate octahedron of Fe4(μ3-O)2(O2C–)8 clusters connected through eight BTB links. These pores are accessible through elliptical apertures measuring 4.0 × 8.0 Å. TGAs indicated that the solvent molecules residing in the pores of 1 could be removed by heating to 150 °C (see the ). Measured adsorption of N2 by 1 at 77 K yielded a reversible, nonhysteretic type-I isotherm. From these data, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir apparent surface areas were calculated as 1121 and 1835 m2 g−1, respectively, and the pore volume was calculated as 0.69 cm3 g−1. The material also reversibly adsorbs up to 2.1 wt % of hydrogen gas at 77 K and 1 bar (see the ).

cln_elements.content: Description of the crystal structure of 1. (a) Thermal ellipsoid plot of a structural fragment highlighting the organic and inorganic SBUs, drawn with 50% probabilities. An inversion center is located in the middle of the Fe4(μ3-O)2 cluster. O(1S) is a DMF oxygen atom, and O(10) is a coordinated water oxygen atom. Hydrogen bonds are drawn as dashed lines. (b) A BTB link can be schematized as a 3-connector; similarly, the Fe4(μ3-O)2(O2C–)8 inorganic SBU is drawn as a prism of vertices. (c) The material is composed of two interpenetrated frameworks, each constructed by linking the SBUs described in (b).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Description of the crystal structure of 1. (a) Thermal ellipsoid plot of a structural fragment highlighting the organic and inorganic SBUs, drawn with 50% probabilities. An inversion center is located in the middle of the Fe4(μ3-O)2 cluster. O(1S) is a DMF oxygen atom, and O(10) is a coordinated water oxygen atom. Hydrogen bonds are drawn as dashed lines. (b) A BTB link can be schematized as a 3-connector; similarly, the Fe4(μ3-O)2(O2C-)8 inorganic SBU is drawn as a prism of vertices. (c) The material is composed of two interpenetrated frameworks, each constructed by linking the SBUs described in (b).

cln_elements.content: (a) CO2 adsorption isotherms of 1 collected at various temperatures. CO2 was reversibly desorbed at each temperature. (b) CO2 adsorption isotherms measured at 273 K for several known MOFs are shown for a comparison. Literature references for each material are listed in the Supporting Information.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) CO2 adsorption isotherms of 1 collected at various temperatures. CO2 was reversibly desorbed at each temperature. (b) CO2 adsorption isotherms measured at 273 K for several known MOFs are shown for a comparison. Literature references for each material are listed in the Supporting Information.

cln_elements.content: Relationships between some decorated forms of the primitive cubic net (pcu) with chemical relevance. Nets are defined by arrays of linked vertices (balls and sticks); polyhedral shading has been added to aid visualization. The net pcu is 6-coordinated; reo is 8-coordinated; sod and lta are 4-coordinated; bor, tbo, and partially augmented the are (3,4)-coordinated; and the is (3,8)-coordinated.

metadata.title: A Porous and Interpenetrated Metal–Organic Framework Comprising Tetranuclear IronIII–Oxo Clusters and Tripodal Organic Carboxylates and Its Implications for (3,8)-Coordinated Networks
